Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n>Output:		florida<n><n># Solution:<n><n>import math<n>import numpy as np<n><n>def get_input():<n>    questions = ["", "", ""]<n>    while True:<n>        try:<n>            questions[0] = input("Give me the name of the first question")<n>            questions[1] = input("Given the name of the first, give me the first question?")<n>            questions[2] = input("Gavne the name of the first...")<n>            return questions<n>        except:<n>            print("Wrong. Try again")<n><n>def multi_choice():<n>    choices = input("Please provide the choices in a seperate list")<n>    return np.array(choices.split(' ')).transpose()<n><n>def calculate_answer(multiple_choice):<n>    answers = []<n>    for i in range(len(multiple_choice)):<n>        answers.append(int(multiple_choice[i][1]))<n>    return np.argmax(answers)<n><n>questions = get_input()<n>multiple_choice = multi_choice()<n># print(questions)<n># print(answers)<n>print(calculate_answer(multiple_choic))<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:What could listening to music cause you to be? Choices:  A: happy B: smile C: calm D: entertainment E: relaxation<n>Output:		D<n><n>### Step 1: Create variables<n>Create variables for the input and output of the game. We also name the input as "word" and the output as "phrase".<n>```python<n>word = 0<n>phrase = 0<n>flag = False<n>```<n>### Step 2: Read the Input<n>We use a loop to iterate over the input lines.<n>```python<n>for word in range(len(words.split())):<n>  if words.split()[word] == '#':<n>    flag=True<n>```  <n>### Step 3: Read the Output<n>Here, we read the output of the game line by line.<n>```python<n>phrase = phrase + '. '<n>	```<n>### Step4: Solving the game<n>Once we have read the input and the output, the idea is to match the second half of the output with the last word and then return True (or False.<n>```python<n>word[-1] == flag<n>```<n>## Step 5: Handle exiting the loop<n>```python<n>```<n><n>### Important notes:<n>A big thanks to all the great resources that brought this content together. Specifically (from top to bottom):<n>1. [Python - 10 Games in 10 Lines](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FoF6Cxg5-g)&nbsp;&nbsp;<n>2. (I used the same games as this video - but with more elegant code!!!)&nbsp;&nbsp;<n>3. My own notes from using this project in class<n>4. The actual code from this week's project from class.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:"There are 10 apples on an apple tree.  Three fall off.  Now there are X apples."  What is this an example of? Choices:  A: park B: coloring book C: garden center D: math problem E: gravity<n>Output:		Gravity<n><n>Input: What is the smallest number that cannot be written as the sum of two positive numbers less than it?<n>Output: 101<n><n>Input: A math problem gives us the equation "3x + 5 = 8".  How many answers would you get if you solved the equation and then chose different values for x?<n>Output: 2 (One solution for each value of x)<n>Notice: For every answer to the question above, one variable (x) is varied over multiple values.  The answer provided will only have one answer when x is a single value.<n>Example: 3x + 5 does not equal 8, but 3(x + 5) = 8 when x = -3.  Two values satisfy the equation after it is satisfied by one value.<n><n>Input: Sam has to choose 4 people to go to a party.  So far, he can choose anyone from a pool of: Sam, George, Alex, Mary Lou, and Chloe.  How many ways can Sam choose 4 people from this pool?<n>Output: 5<n><n>![code]({{ site.baseurl }}/images/math-problem-code/math-problem-00.png)<n><n>![screenshot 01]({{ site.baseUrl }}/images/math/math-problem-screenshot-00.png){:.center-image }<n><n>![screenshow 02]({{ site.baseURL }}/images/mathpuzzles/math-problem-2-screenshot-2.png){:.shadow-image.pull-left } <n><n>![screenshoot 03]({{ site.basePath }}/images/math2/math-problem-3-screenshot-3.png){:.border-image.pull-right  }<n>![screenshoow 04]({{ site.baseUtlr }}/images/mathproblems/math-problem-4-screenshot-4.png){:.shade.pull-left }<n>![screen shot 05]({{ site.basepath }}/images/math3/math-problem-5-screenshot-5.png){:.gray.pull-right }<n><n>![screeshot 06]({{ site.baseDirectory }}/images
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:What could prevent someone from buying chistmas presents? Choices:  A: happiness B: lack of money C: stress D: relief E: exhiliration<n>Output:		E <n><n>### Instruction:Answer the previous multiple choice question in words.<n><n>The total number of legs is equal to the total number of kangaroos plus the total number of goats. Mark has 23 kangoaroos. So, we know that there are 23 kangaroo legs. He, then, has three times as many goat legs as kangaroo legs which we can write as 3L. That is, if his goat legs were doubled then the two numbers would be the same but there is only one goat leg. So, we know we have to multiply 3 by the number we are looking for, we multiply the number of kangaroo legs times the number of goat legs. We know that we have 23 kangasoos and 3 times as many goat leg and there are an even number of goat legs times an even number of kangaros which is 46. We know that the total number of legs combined is 69. It is now up to us to solve for the number that we are trying to find. So, we cross multiply and see that the answer is 46.<n>

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. A million<n>Output: A. 2<n><n>Input: What does an apple have that no other fruits do? Choices:A: A seed B: a core C: A pit D: A pit that is part of the seed E: Something with a face<n>Output: D. Choices:  A: growing older B: reproducing C: shuddering D: perspiration E: palpitations<n>Output:		 Choice: E and E <n><n>### Instruction:Complete the function below so that it returns the input with all occurrences of "D" changed to "C".<n><n>Input: "Hello, Dear Dad."<n>Output: "Hello, Dew Dad."<n><n>def redo(string):<n>    final_result = []<n>    for char in string:<n>        if char == 'C' or char =='D':<n>            final_result.append('O')<n>            if char=='C':<n>                final_result.append("C")<n>                return''.join(final_result)<n>            else:<n>                final_result[-1] = 'C'<n>    return''.join(list(zip('C',final_result)))<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the function below and return the index of the first vowel in s.<n><n>def find_a_vowel(s):<n>    vowels = ["a", "i", "e", "u"]<n>    i = 0<n>    for letter in s:<n>        if letter in vowels:<n>            i = i+1<n>    while i+1 < len(s):<n>        if s[i] in vowels: <n>            break<n>        i = i+1 <n>    return i+1<n><n>### Instractions: Write an even longer version of the first one that goes through all n letters.  Think about the order it goes through the letters for this one.<n><n>### Instuctions: Complete the function below and return "apple" and "grape".<n><n>def find_letters_with_prefix_prefix_length(s, length, startPosition=0):<n>    vowel = ["a", "e", "i", "o", "u"]<n><n>    for i in range (startPosition, len(s)):<n>        if s[startPosition] is in vowel:<n>            return "".join(s[:i-startPosition + 1])<n>        else:<n>            pass<n><n>### Instuactions: Your function needs to return True if the word ends in a word that also ends in "a", "e", or "i", and vice versa. (So, for example, "aardvark" and "deer" are both valid, even

One shows a number three, another shows that number will be drawn as a one, and another shows that it will be drawn as two.  The final result will show these three images combined, showing how many times each letter is used to represent the number.<n><n>Input: One/two/three<n>Output: 1/11/31<n><n>---<n><n>Input:What about one if it's in your mind instead of your home? Choices:  A: geography B: history studies C: math D: religion E: dancing<n>Output:		 geography<n><n><n>import math<n><n>def countLegs(list_of_animal):<n>    numberOfLegs = 0<n>    if len(list_of_Animal) == 0 :<n>        print("We have a problem! we can't count you're legs if we don't even see how many legs you have!")<n>        return 0, "We have a problem! We can't count your legs if we don'<n>if len(list_ofList_ofAnimal) % 1 == 0: # check the percentage of how many items in the list are there, and if it is divisible by 1 then it is a valid list<n>    for x in list_ofList_ofAnimals:<n>        if len(list_Of_ofAnimal) <=3:<n>            numberOfLegs = len(list_OfAnimal)  #  in this case, no need for loop, just print the values directly<n>        elif len(list_OfAnimals) <= 3:<n>            number_of_Legs = sum((x.getLeg()) + (x.getLeg()) )/ 2 - 1<n>        else:<n>            numberOf_legs = sum((x+1).getLeg() for x in list_Of_animal)- 1<n>    <n>    answer = str(number_Of_legs) + " of legs"<n>    return answer, "It means you have..."<n><n># for testing the code in the same function  <n>def testFunction_of_a_Funtion():<n>    answer = 0<n>    number_Of_legs =0<n>    list_of_Animal = ['Goat','goat','Pig','pig','Rabbit','rabbit'<n>             ,'Bat','Bat']<n><n>    list_ofList_Animal = [<n>                    [['Goat','goat'],<n>                     ['Bat','Bat'],<n>                     [['Pig','pig'],['Bat','Bat',]<n>                    ]<n><n>    ]<n><n>    value = countLegs(listOfListOfAnimal)<n>    print (value)<n><n>if __name__ == "__main__":<n>   testFunction_of_A_function<n><n><n>

Choices:  a: Mexico b: New York c: New Mexico d: California<n>Output: a<n><n>Input: Which planet takes the longest time to orbit the Sun in its own orbit? Choices: 1. Jupiter 2. Mercury 3. Venus 4. Uranus 5. Mars<n>Output: 3<n><n>Input: What country has the capital city London? Choices:  C: Scotland d: Canada b: England A: USA e: Ireland <n>Output: c<n><n>Input: Find me the country which starts with the letter H and has an island named Newfoundland.<n>Output: Canada<n><n>Input: What letter comes after A, B, C, D, E, F and G?<n>Output: H<n><n>Input: What does BAE go with BLA?  Choices: Choices: 1: BLANA 2: BLANA and BANANA 3: BAANA and BLANA 4: BANANA and BLNA

She is 97 lbs.  How much does her father weigh?<n>Output: 20<n><n>If mary weighs 3 pounds, her father weighs 20 pounds.  That means that she (mary) weighed 82 pounds before she lost 97 pounds.  So 82/97 = 84/97<n><n>So her father weighs (497 = 83.8 which is close enough to 20, rounding)<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>If you are working from home and need to work online, try to take a picture of your keyboard to be sure that you didn't leave it behind. <n><n>What's the purpose of a keyboard picture? <n><n>To be able to tell from the picture what the person is typing.<n><n>What else do you often have with you? Your phone, ipad or laptop (which can be used to share keyboard pictures).<n><n>Your laptop.

Each student in the class will use roughly equally their share of the paper each day, though some students will need more or less paper than other students.  The paper is 75% used up by 3 students.  The paper has the shape of a rectangular prism with a width of 8 cm, a height of 5 cm and a length of 12 cm.  The students need to determine if there is sufficient paper for each student.  It is known that one student needs 126.5 pieces of paper and the other 110.5 pieces of paper.  How much paper does the students have available?<n>Output:284.5

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:What does someone living life fully feel? Choices:  A: joy B: valuable C: happiness D: early death E: adventurous<n>Output:		A<n><n><n>### Part 1 Solution:<n><n>You will need three for loops. The outermost loop, will run once per line in the input. The second loop, will run twice. The inner loop, will run once. Let's explain in each step, the value of all variables.<n><n>### a, b, i, n<n><n>a, b, i, and n are all declared. Let's think about a in more detail. It will store the input.<n><n>### c, j, k, m<n><n>c and j will keep track of our "index" of each line. So, c is one and j is the number of lines that we need to go through.<n><n>### d, k, numToAdd, num, x, y<n><n>The variables will come into play as we loop through the file, and through the two loops within the outer loop.<n><n>d, our flag to track "has added all of the ones"<n><n>k, will be two. k should be two.<n><n>numToAdd, will let us know how much to add to our line.<n><n>num, will count the number of spaces we should move to the right of our string.<n><n>x, is initialized to 0, or zero.<n><n>y, is initialized to 1.<n><n>

Add it to a positive? Subtract a positive from a negative? E: The victim was murdererd by a drug addict.<n>Output: The victim was murderered by a drug addict and the cops knew who it was and did not give any information to the public. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. Choices: 1: ball of fur 2: a baby cat 3: no such thing<n>Output: A kitten is a baby cat<n>Input: What has fur?  Choices: Kids Pizza dogs Bears<n>Output: Dogs has fur.<n><n><n><n><n><n>108010<n><n>$$\begin{align}{\rm 1.1\times \times } &{\rm 10}\end{align}$$<n><n>01111<n><n>$$\begin{gathered}\begin{aligned} {\rm 4.2+2.7}\hfill \\ {\rm =6.9}\hfill \\ {\end{aligned}\quad }\hfill \\ \end{gathered}$$<n><n>00566<n><n>$$\begin {align}{\rm \rm 8.9\times \times }&{\rm 12\rm }\end{align} $$<n><n>10000<n><n>$$\begin\rm 0 = 0 \quad\rm \rm 0,5 =\rm\ \rm 0.5 \quad\rm\ \rm 10 =\rm\ 10\rm\ \end\rm $$<n><n>112121<n><n>$$\frac{p_1+p_2-1}{2}$$<n><n>00370<n><n>$$\frac{\rm \rm\ 8.9^{49}}{\rm 8.9^{2}\rm}\quad\rm\ \quad\quad\rm\ \ \quad \rm\ \ \quad\rm\quad $$<n><n>106640<n><n>$$\sqrt[3]{5}-18 \quad\rm\rm \rm\rm\quad $$

Input:<n>[7, 8, 9], [2, 4, 6] Output: true <n>```javascript<n>function interleaving(arr1, arr2) {<n>  if (arr1.length!== arr2.length) return false<n>  <n>  for (let i = 0; i < arr1.length; i++) {<n>    if (arr1[i]!== arr2[i]) return false<n>  }<n>  return true<n>}<n>```<n><n><n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Given an array of strings, determine if the array is a palindrome of strings.<n>Input: ["a man, a plan", "a canal--"]<n>Output: true<n>```javascript<n>function isPalindrome(arr) {<n>  if(!arr) return true<n>  return arr[0] === arr[arr.length - 1] || isPalindrome(getReversed(arr))<n>}<n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:John ran out of pencils.  Where did  he go to get more? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: cup C: pencil case D: shelf E: office depot<n>Output:		 C<n><n>Input:Ashley has ten eggs. How many times can the eggs be divided into two equal groups? Choices: 4, 6, 8, 10, 12<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input:Today is 19th January 1981.  How many minutes are in this day? Choices: 1449 minutes 1450 minutes 1451 minutes 1452 minutes 1453 minutes<n>Output: 1453<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the above question using while or do-while loop.<n><n>### Solution:<n>![solution](https://github.com/kumarvigneshwaran/KVW-MCQ-Questions/blob/gh-pages/Images/Loop%20Question%20Solution.PNG)<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following MCQ.<n>### Solution:I have not added the solution for this question yet on my website. Describe an application that you would use this data structure for.<n><n>A data structure that is used to store data and allows the insertion and deletion of elements at both ends but not the other end is called a Stack. A Stack is a data structure that is designed to make element addition simpler at one end and also element removal simpler at the other end. A data structure that is used for storing data so that insertion and removal of data elements can be done at either end is called a Stack and there are two operations that are used to manipulate data in a Stack:<n><n>Push() Operations: This operation allows you to put elements in a stack.<n>Pop() Operations: This is the reverse of a Push() operation, which is used to remove each element from the stack.<n>These two operations are applied using push and pop. A Stack has three methods that are used to manage a Stack:<n><n>push() and pop() and size() are used for manipulating the data structure, and <n><n>peek() and empty() are used to read the data out of the stack.<n>Input: 95665    Output: 107495<n><n>Input:88   Output:3<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:Where would you find some swords in your house? Choices:  A: sheath B: sword closet C: collection D: container called scabbard E: museum<n>Output:		 B<n><n>Input: A robot has a laser sight  What do we call the laser with in this situation? Choices:  E: weapon  B: scope  E: armament  A: sight  D: sight<n>Output: E: weapon<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>1. The answer is **44**.<n><n>   89 stickers - (3 + 7 x 6) = 44<n><n>2. The answer is **6**.<n><n>   100 - 65 - (5 + 10 + 7 x 2)/2 = 6<n><n>3. The answer is **322**.<n><n>23 * 3 = 72 - 72 = 0<n><n>4. A is the correct answer.<n><n>Mary has her other pages with the stickers intact.<n><n>5. E is the correct answer.

We will run it with the machine set to input from STDIN and output to STDOUT.  The program will be given as a binary integer (base 2) string.  For example, if the program would output 'hello' as the output, it would be given input of "00101".  The first string (the first row) would be one binary number long, the second string (the second row) would be two binary numbers long, etc.<n><n>The number of rows and columns for each program will always be equal to the size of the input (rows = input.length and columns = input.length).  Each row in your program would be one binary number longer than the binary input.  For example, 4 rows given input of "0110" would need to be the binary representation of 4x4 numbers plus one extra row (0001).  This ensures that the last row is correct, which would be the last binary number given to the program in its input.<n><n>We will not give you a test file or example program or input/output to use to check your code beforehand.  You can use the online binary calculator (see below) and the online binary converter for decimal numbers (see below) to debug your program.<n><n>#### Binary Calculator:https://www.binaryconverter.net/binary-calculator<n><n>#### Binary Converter:https://www.convertbinary.com<n><n>### Input and Output:<n>#### Example Input:<n>`0101000110001`<n><n>#### Example Output:<n>`0001110`<n><n>###

The Mayans wanted a calendar because they had to keep track <n><n>of time.  <n><n>#### 2C:<n>How does the water in rivers change over time?<n><n>A: It cools and warms, rises and falls<n><n>B: It sinks and gathers into oceans<n><n>C: It evaporates into clouds and rains in other rivers<n><n>D: It remains in the same spot<n><n>#### 2D:<n>What event influenced the fall of Athens? <n><n>A) a civil war<n><n>B) A plague <n><n>C) The rise of Alexander the Great, who took all of Greece <n><n><n>#### 2E:<n>Why does water freeze?<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:Where will a native lemur be found? Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n>Output:		 correct. it is a native lemur (D) A lemur is a native of Madagascar.<n><n>Input: How many pairs of animals in the world have only two legs? Choices:  One pair: a dog and a cat and two pairs: a horse and a cat and a squirrel and a rabbit.<n>Output: correct. Dogs, cats, and squirrels have only two legs.<n><n>Input: Which is bigger, a whale or a humpback whale? Choices: A: a whale B: a humpback whlse C: the whale<n>Output:  correct: Both the whale and the humpback whale are bigger than a dog.<n><n>Input: If a sheep's ear is bigger than a cat's ear which is bigger, the cat or the sheep? Choices: A sheep ear, B Cat ear,  C Cow ear is the biggest<n><n>Output:  correct, cat is bigger than sheep<n>```<n><n>---<n><n><n>```python<n>def my_program(n_stickers, n_large, n_pages, n_stickers_remaining):<n>	global n_stickers,n_large,n_pages,n_stickers_remaing<n>	n_stickers = n_stickers + 4 #n_stickers becomes n_stickers+4 since the first and second conditions were true.<n>	n_large = 3<n>	n_pages = n_pages * 7<n>	n_stikers_remaining = n_stickesr_remaining - n_stickes_remaining<n>```<n><n>---
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:Turkey is a nation in what part of the world? Choices:  A: middle east B: asia minor C: asia D: provide meat E: balkan peninsula<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input:Mike has 40 apples.  He eats 2 apples every day.  How many days does he have apples?<n>Output: 200<n><n>Input:The city where I was born is Tianjin, and it is 120 miles from Beijing. The city where my parent was born is Nanjing, and it is 440 miles from Beijng. I can drive a 800-mile trip in 9 days. I will meet my parents in Beijing. How many days will I stay with them?<n>Output: 10<n><n>Input:How much bread do you want to eat per week?<n>Output: 7 or 1 or 11 or 14 or 17<n><n>Output: 478<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the multiple choice question.<n>There are a small number of questions below with multiple answer options.  Answer the question according to the statement.  You may have to combine options if it makes sense (for example:  a and b together).  The answer options in parentheses are in the order they are in.<n><n>Input:Is a statement (1, 2, 3, 4, 5) true or false?<n>Output: true or false<n><n><n>Input:Is the pair (A, c) a permutation or a combination?<n>Output: a permutation or a combinaton<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>Input:The two cities separated by 2000 miles and there are 5 airports on each city, each airport can support 600 passenger at most. the train can support max 200 passenger. the bus can support max 10 passenger. How many people will travel to each place?<n>Output: 0 or 6 or 12 or 134 or 313<n><n>Input:Mary is walking down the street and the first house is 100 meters away from the starting point and each house is the same distance apart. The street is 150 meters long. How many doors are on the street?<n>Output: 94<n><n>Input:A set of four bags contains a yellow ball, a red ball, and a purple ball. You are blindfolded

Lisa eats 3 cookies and a cupcake.  If they both want their calorie intake to be an even 16, each with one sandwich and one cookie remaining, who will get the remaining snacks from each?<n>Output: Johnny gets the remaining cookies and candy bar and Lisa gets the remaining cupcake.<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:He needed to check an electrical connection in the house, where did he look? Choices:  A: telephone network B: freeway C: company D: wall E: airport<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: A person had 4 sons and 6 daughters. If each child has brothers equal to the number of sisters, then how many children did she have in total?<n>Output: 10<n><n>Input: An ant crawls 3 cm to the right, then 5 cm to the left, then 8 cm to the right, and then 9 cm to the left. What is the final position of the ant?<n>Output: 2 cm below the starting point<n><n>Input: What is 6 minus 2? <n><n>Output: 39228<n><n>####################<n>### 1. <n><n>class Calculator:<n><n>    def __init__(self, display, add = None, subtract = None):<n>        self.display = display<n>        self.add = add<n>        self.subtract = subtract<n>        <n>    def run(self, instruction):<n>        command = instruction.split(" ")<n>        self.display.show(command[0])<n>        self.display(command[1])<n><n>    def add(self):<n>        self.run(self.add)<n><n>    def subtract(self):<n>        if self.subtract == None:<n>            return<n>        self.run("SUBTRACT");<n><n><n><n><n><n>def main():<n>    <n>    print("----------------------------------")<n>    print("Welcome to Tynus")<n>    print("Enter instruction to use the calculator:")<n>    print("   PRESS -1 to go to the previous page")<n>    print("-----------------")<n>    <n>    result =[]<n>    user = input("What is your name?")<n>    display = Display()<n>    <n>    for line in user.split():<n>        line = line.strip()<n>        if len(line) == 0:<n>            continue<n>        result.append(line)<n>        calculator = Calculator(display, add=subtract)<n>        user = input("What's your command?")<n>        <n>        <n>    for line in result:<n>        calculator.run(line)<n><n>if __name__ == "__main__":<n>    main()<n>

A large pie is equal to 8 slices. A medium sized pizza has 4 slices per large pie and has 6 slices. A small pizza has 2 slices per large pizza and has 6 slicers. How many slices are there in an American Pizza?<n>"A pizza has 6*6 slices per large pies. A large pie is 8 slices. Therefore, a large pie is 56 slices and we subtract 6*6-56 because we take away 6 times 6-8 times 6 and that equals the rest of the slices"<n><n>Input: There is a 57 inch tall <n><n>Output: turtle<n><n>Input: 2 + 6*4/6 + 4 + 4*3 + 10*6 + 11<n>Output: 47<n>

Using the 'not in' will give you True or False, but by simply writing a new for loop and checking for True or False depending on if it's the right answer, it is more straightforward to write a program than the 'not in' method. The 'and' function is a logical operator. The reason I had the 'not in' operator not working was because a True or False output does not make sense because the whole purpose of the question is for the user to figure out that it would not work. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. Choices:  A: city B: strip mall C: clerk D: neighborhood E: rooster<n>Output:		A<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the questions related to following code.<n><n>```javascript<n>let city = ""<n><n>function doInput(city) {<n>  console.log("doing input...")<n>  if (city === "strip mall") {<n>    let stripMalls = {<n>      city: "strip mall",<n>      state: "strip mall"   <n>    }<n>    console.log("This is strip mall: ", stripMalls)<n>    city = "stripmall"<n>  } else if (city === "city") {<n>    let city = {<n>      city,<n>      state: "city"<n>    }<n>    city = "city"<n>    console.log('This is a city: ', city)<n>  } else if(city === "clerk") {<n>    let clerk = {<n>      city<n>    }<n>    clerk = "clerk"<n>    console.info("Here is clerk: ", clerk)<n>  } else {<n>    city = "neighborhood"<n>    console.error("you did not choose any of above options")<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>```<n>Input: The teacher calls the student to the front of the class.  The class is having a contest on how many times a certain letter appears in the word 'cabbage.'  If the students do not know how to find out they can ask you.  The teacher tells the student that the contest is a winner-take-all contest and the class could use whatever you find out for free to win the contest.  How many times does a c appear in the word 'cabbage'?<n>Output: 1<n><n>Input: The teacher tells the class that the words in the word 'cake' repeat twice and adds that the class could always ask you to help them.  She also tells them that she got the idea to have the contest from you.  The class thinks that they should ask you for help since they know you know how many times the letter 'a' appears in the word 'cafeteria.'  Do they need to ask for your help?<n>Output: No<n>```<n><n>## What did you learn from it?<n><n> - This was a good challenge to test my knowledge in some basics of JavaScript.

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:John is studying animals.   What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n>Output:		A<n><n><n>```python<n>numStickers=int(input()) #getting input<n>large = 3<n>used=0 #initializing<n>for i in range(1,numStickers+1):#iterating<n>    numStickers-=large<n>    used+=i<n>if(used<=0):<n>    print(15)<n>else:<n>    print(13)<n><n><n>money=int(input())#getting input<n>weekAllowance=5<n>lawnPay=$10#initializing<n>babyPay=7<n>remainingMoney=$65 #storing after subtracting lawn pay,baby pay and week allowance<n>if(money<=remainingMoney):<n>    print(22)<n>else:<n>    <n>    hoursWork=int(input())<n>    if(hoursWork==0):<n>        pass<n>    else:<n>        pay = money - remainingMoney<n>        print(8/hoursWork)<n>        pay = int(pay*(hoursWork/8))<n>        print(10)<n>        while(pay<0):<n>            print(10)#printing 9 times<n>            pay+=-1<n>            print(11)<n>else:<n><n>    answer=input()<n>    if(answer=="A" or answer=="C"):<n>        dieOfCancer=int(input())+1<n>        print(6)<n>    else:<n><n>        print(1)<n><n>```<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:Where would one find a captive monkey? Choices:  A: rain forest B: tree tops C: toy store D: zoological gardens E: great outdoors<n>Output:		C<n><n>Input: A tiger is fast, a deer is nimble, a monkey is clever.  What is the smartest of all?<n>Output: ANSWER IS NOT ALREADY ATTEMPTED. <n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:If someone is outgoing what are they likely to seek? Choices:  A: new experiences B: playfulness C: own house D: good looking E: beautiful<n>Output:		C<n><n>Input:The sum of two numbers is 35. One of the numbers is 4 less than the other. What is the smaller of the two numbers? Choices: 1) 4 B) 7 C) 9 D) 12 E) 14<n>Output: B<n><n>Input:How many letters are in the word "Fortran"? <n>Output: 9

A mouse has 4 legs. How many legs do you have? Output: 2  If you had 3, how many pencils would you have to get 5? Output: 5 If you have 8, how many pencil would  you have to get 10? Output: 9<n><n>Input: A giraffe has 4 legs. Kangaroos are mammals, and kangaroos have 2 legs.  How many more legs does a giraffe have than a kangaroo?  Output: 2 <n><n>Input:A  lion's  tail has 2  prongs and a deer's  tail has  3  prongs.  How many prongs do all the animal's tails have together? Output: 5 <n><n>Input: A whale has no legs, but it has 20 bones and 44 teeth.  A turtle has no bones and 16 teeth. What animal has the most bones?<n><n>Output: turtle<n><n>Input: There are 10 pencils on the table. Input: Mary had 8   sticker.   She used 3 large  stickers on the front  page of her journal   and 7 stickers each  to six other pages of her journal.. How many   stickers does Mary have  remaining?<n>Output:mary had 8 sticker<n>    <n>sticker: 1,2,3<n>    <n>mary had 8 x 3<n>1/8 = 3/8<n>makery had 3 sticker on the front page journal(3/8)<n>     <n>mary use 7 stick on each page of her journal

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:Where do  you park in the parking lot with shopping bags? Choices:  A: amusement park B: urban area C: airport D: shopping malls E: train station<n>Output:		E<n><n>#### Solution: <n>### Part 1<n>---<n>```java<n>import java.util.*;<n>public class Instruction {<n>    public static void main(String[] args) {<n>        Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);                           //   <n>        int answer = scan.nextInt();                                       //   <n>        scan.nextLine();                                                //  .<n><n>        for (int i = 0; i < answer; i++) {<n>            System.out.print("#");<n>        }<n>        System.out.println();<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:If I wanted to store dirt in my home, where could I put it? Choices:  A: fingernails B: garden C: corner D: computer E: closet<n>Output:		 E: closet<n><n>### Explanation:<n>#### Answer:A<n>```<n>#!/usr/bin/python<n>n = int(input("How many stickers are being used?")) #How many stickers are you using?<n>stickers =0<n>start = 7<n>end = n<n>n -= start<n>if (end!= n+ start):<n>print("Entered value of 'n' is: "+n)<n>print("stickers left behind: "+end)<n>    else:<n>    print("Entered value of n + start(before: %d) is: %d and value after end is:",n,end)<n>    print("Enterd value of stickers are: %d" %stickers);<n>```<n>#### Answer:B<n>```<n>#!/bin/python<n>m = input("How much did you spent? ") #m is the money they spent, it is a string<n>print(end ="00") #the zero<n>d = m[0] #to know which number is in front<n>decimal= m[len(m)-1:]<n>amount1= int(m) - int(decimal)<n>amount2 = amount1 / 100<n>amount3, amount4 = amount2 / 10, amount2 % 10<n>amount5 = amount3 / 10<n><n>print("the amount is %d" %amount1)<n>print("How much is the amount after dividing 100: %d" %amount2)<n>print("How many times is %d divide by 10?: %d" %(amount3, amount1) )<n>print("Lastly, how many times %d divided by 10?: " %(amount4) )<n>print("the answer %d" %amount5)<n>```<n>#### Answer B:<n>```<n>#!/use/bin/python<n>x =int( input ("How many are you using on the front page?") )<n>y = 0<n>z = 0<n>num = 1<n>while num <=y :<n>	num = x- num<n>	if x > 0:<n>		print(x)<n>		x -= 1<n>	else: z += 1<n>		print(z)<n>	num += 1<n>```<n>#### Answer E:<n>```

She had used 3 large ones on the front page of the journal and 7 other ones on 6th pages of the journal. So Mary has 57 stickers left.<n><n>Zach is saving his money to buying bike. His weekly allowance was $5. His parent pay him an extra $ 10 to mow lawn and neighbor will pay for babysit their kid. He made $65 till now. He will get allowance on Friday and babysit for two hours this Saturday after mowing the lawn. Total money he need to buy a bike was 21.<n><n>Mark has kangaroos an goats. Kangaroos have 2 legs, and goat has 4 legs. If he has 2 times as many goats are kangaroos then total number of animals legs is 234= 86.<n><n>My answer:<n><n>Jim always goes home to home and he never spent the entire evening in anywhere else. <n><n>Anthony always goes home to home. So he never spends the entire evening anywhere else.<n>### Instruction answer the multiple choice questions below.<n><n>Input: How is the number 47 written in words? If I pick one of the coins at random, what is the probability that Ill choose a dime?<n>Output: 0.095<n><n>Input: If the probability that you pick a red ball from a large box of mixed red, blue and green balls is.25, what is the probability you'll pick a blue ball?<n>Output: 1-(.25) =.75<n><n>------------------<n><n># [Chapter 3] - Constructs & Conditionals<n><n>### Instructions:Answer all questions at the bottom then click submit to check your answer<n><n>### Instructio:Input:<n>A: Write an if-else-if conditional where the final value will never be true.<n>Output: None<n>Output: None<n>B: Write a for statement that repeats a range of values 1 to 6. Subtract 1 from each value that is even, and add 1 to each value that is odd.<n>Output:<n>C: How can you find the largest of the three numbers? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:Remembering past successe is likely to cause what? Choices:  A: problems B: crying C: inspiration D: trauma E: nightmares<n>Output:		inspiration<n><n>---<n>```powershell<n>#region function<n>function convertToBinary ([int]$number)<n>{<n>    $numToConv = $(ConvertTo-sByte   $number )#the original number is converted into binary sequence and saved in a variable<n>    $numToSup = $numToConv/2#the above binary sequence is divided into two and the divisor of the operation is removed and saved<n>    $numToTri = $numToSup/3#the divisor of the above process of subtraction is converted into two and the divisors of the operation are stored<n>    write-host $numToConv<n>    write-host "`n $numToSup<n>    write-host "- $numToTri<n>}<n>#endregion function<n><n>[int]$number = Convertto-sByte -value 10<n>convertToBinary $number<n><n>ConvertByteToInt -Byte $number | Out-Null<n><n>function convertByteToInt ($byte)<n>{#it will convert an 8bit number to its binary equivalent.<n>    $numStr = ""<n>    for ($i=7; $i -ge 0; 1)<n>    {<n>        $numStr += "0"<n>        if (($byte -gt16) -and ($byte -lt 84))<n>        {<n>            $i = 9<n>        }<n>        elseif($byte -le 16)<n>        {<n>            write-host "inside the 7th line"<n>            if ($i -le 8)<n>            {<n>                $i =  9<n>            }<n>        }<n>        $byte=$byte >> 1 #bit shifting the byte variable.<n><n>    }<n>    return [int]$numStr<n>}<n>```<n>```powershell<n>$data3 = $(Get-Content -Path "C:\Temp\Data3.txt")<n>$data4 = $(Get-Content "C:\Temp\data4.txt")<n><n>$convert3 = ConvertByteToInt -Byte $(ConvertFrom-StringData -InputObject $data4)<n>Write-Host $convert3<n>```

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n>Output:		E<n><n>Input:  There are three cakes.  They are chocolate, strawberry and carrot.  What cake could be on the cake plate if there is 1 white spot, 1 red spot and at least 1 brown spot?<n>Output: Carrot<n><n>Input:  One day in May there were 3 tulips, 2 roses, 5 carnations, 8 daisies, 12 lilies, 7 lilacs, 6 orchids, 9 violets, and 12 jonquils on a spring bouquet.  How many flowers were on the bouquet the day in May? Choice A: 59 B: 53 C: 68 D: 55 E: 60<n>Output: 60<n>Instructions: Please answer all questions in the worksheet.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:What would be considered a success when attempting procreation? Choices:  A: celebrate B: have party C: hear crowd go mad D: create success E: reproduce<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: Find the sum of all numbers to be subtracted from 10 if the number of different integers to be multiplied by 7 is 10.<n>Output:375<n><n>Input: What is 1000 divided by 340.<n>Output: 2.8<n>#!/usr/bin/python<n>from __future__ import print_function<n><n>def solve_multiples():<n>    n=int(input().split(' ')[2])<n>    for x in xrange(1, n+1):<n>        m2=1<n>        while m2<=x:<n>            m=m2<n>            m2+=1<n>            print(m+m2)<n><n>def solve_subs():<n>    numberToSub=int(input().title().split(' ')[1])<n>    for i in range(1,numberToSub,8):<n>        try:<n>            numberWithOut=list((input().title().split('.')[1:3]))[0]<n>            #print(numberWithOut.split('/')[1])<n>            print (numberWithOut.split()[0]*int(numberWithOut.replace('/','')))<n>        except indexError:<n>            pass<n>    for i in (x*numberToSub for x in range(1, input().split().title().count(' ') + range(1,3))):<n>        print (i)<n><n>#Call our functions here!!!<n>solve_multiples()<n>solve_subs()

Who took out just enough to make it so?<n>Output: student 26<n><n>Input: There's 3 of us so we need to buy 3 books.  4 people bought 1 book total, how many people bought 0 books?<n>Output: 1<n><n>Input: a student multiplies 2 and 5.  His grade on the problem is 0%.  He multiplies 4 and 2 total.  He gets 5 as the result.  What is his grade on the problem?<n>Output: 0<n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:Where can you see a mammoth in NYC? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: museum exhibit C: prehistoric times D: museum of natural history E: forest<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: 1 of these words is not an English language (French, Portugese, Italian and German) What is it?<n>Output:French<n><n>Input:You take turns flipping coins: you get to flip first - how many coins do you need to keep flipping until you see 4 heads in a row?<n>Output:12<n><n>Input: The total value of a stock is $100 and the stock splits two times, each time in half.  When the stock split two times previously, it was worth $20.  When it split three times previously, it was $6. Now it splits for the fourth time.  Find the price of the stock per share when it splits.<n>Output:$3.125<n><n>Input:Matthew had 38 fish. Which person would typically win a race?<n>Output: A<n>Input:The number of seconds in a day is 24 * 60 * 60.  This means that we can write 60^2 * 60, so that means 60^3 * 60. Since an even number raised to the power of an odd number is the same as its cube, this can be simplified to 60^3 = 60 * 120 * 121 which equals 120^2 * 121. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:How do you indicate that you agree wtih someone? Choices:  A: like more B: nodding C: by wearing rings D: concordance E: shake hands<n>Output:		concordance<n><n>Input:John wants to write a song about caves with some facts about caves.  How many times should he have to copy and paste the word "cave" if he had only one "d" in his spelling of "cave"?<n>Output: 3<n><n>Input:What are the minimum number of letters, if any, that must be removed from the spelling of the word "want" to retain the original sentence and not get the same letter-count that you started with?<n>Output: 1<n><n><n># Solution:<n>```python<n>def mary(n):<n>    return n - 10*3 - 4<n>```<n><n>```python<n>def zach(k,a,h):<n>    l = k + a + h<n>    return k - l<n><n>def mark_kangr(k,g,n):<n>    if k == g:<n>        k += 2<n>    return k<n><n>def mark_goat(a,g):<n>    return a/2<n><n>def john_caves(c,d):<n>    c = c-d+1<n>    return c<n>```<n><n><n># Question:<n><n>The answers above were correct, but which one of the above programs is the most efficient? Explain why.<n><n>## Solution:<n>**`zach`**<n>## Testing Result:<n>```python<n>mary(89) == 44<n>zach(7,10,6) == 6<n>mark_kangr(23,3,3) == 3*2+2 = 32<n>mark_goat(3,2) == 2<n>john_caves(23,3*2) == 3*3<n>```<n>----<n><n>**The function `zach` is the most efficient, because**<n>```python<n>zach(100, 5, 6) == 6,<n>zach(50,2,4) == 4,<n>zach(49,1,2) == 1 and<n>zach(-49,1,-2) == -1<n>```<n><n>----<n><n><n>* * *<n><n>### Other<n><n>## Author:<n><n>* Jongho Shin

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Output: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Output: 322<n><n>Input:You weren't suppose to touch the wild animals, they could what? Choices:  A: lie down B: run away C: bite D: keep alive E: feel pain<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: What part of the body needs to be moving to hear? Choices:  The head B The eyes C The tongue D The skin<n>Output: The skin<n><n>Input: What is an average of a number of fruits? Choices:  No fruit A: 3 B: 4 C: 5 D: 6<n>Output: D<n><n>Input: How many sides does every triangle have? Choices: An odd number  An even number of choices:  No triangle<n>Output: An even number<n><n>input: How many times does two times two equal?  Which option is correct?  Choices: A: 2 times 2, 4 times, 40. B: 2 times 1 time 2, 4 B: 2 times X,4<n><n>Output: B<n>'''<n><n>input = input().split(' ')<n>options = [[b for b in x] for x in input]<n><n>result = (options)<n><n>while True:<n><n>    try:<n>        x = input()<n>    except Exception:<n>         break<n><n>    if x not in options:<n>        pass<n><n>    else:<n>        result.append(x)<n><n>print(result)<n><n><n>"""<n>input:<n>[[0, 1, 2], [3, 4, 5], [7, 8, 9], [6, 10, 11]]<n>"""
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.
